utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF ORGAN)
According to the local Protestant pastor, those visits led to the Heinz family donating more than $56,000 toward restoring his church's 1775 baroque organ.
(SOUNDBITE OF ORGAN)
By comparison, there are no obvious links to Trump in Kallstadt.
The ancestral home has been renovated and resold a number of times.
Village Mayor Thomas Jaworek says the last Trump moved away from Kallstadt a while ago.
So now I think it's more the Heinz ketchup which makes us well-known worldwide.
But perhaps if Donald Trump becomes president, then it might change.
And the Trump family is more important to Kallstadt.
The village's neighbors aren't waiting, however, to poke fun at its Trump connection.
For instance, a nearby town's newspaper called Die Rheinpfalz, earlier this week, superimposed an image of the Trump world tower onto a picture of the Kallstadt skyline.
The paper told readers, that's where the next wine festival will be held.
Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson, NPR News, Kallstadt.
There are alternatives to turkey, from tofu to spaghetti carbonara, which is what Calvin Trillin says the Pilgrims would have chosen if they'd just known about it.
But the center of most traditional Thanksgivings is that browned bird in the middle of the table.
Now, it's just basic economics that when demand increases, so does price - except not for turkeys, during the Thanksgiving season.
The prices will sort of be bumping along, doing their thing throughout the year, and then in November there's a huge drop.
That's Catherine Rampell, an economics reporter for the New York Times.
She says prices of frozen turkeys actually go down by about 10 percent between October and November.
There's more than one theory to explain that drop in turkey prices.
Catherine Rampell says one is that turkey is a loss leader that food stores can use just to get shoppers in the door.
So, maybe they're taking a loss on the turkey, but the consumer comes in and buys cranberries, buys potatoes, buys a turkey baster, all of these other things.
Prices for avocados drop right before the Super Bowl, too, when a lot of guacamole gets made.
But Valentine's Day bucks that price drop trend.
Roses are popular for that holiday, and it turns out that roses are fussier than turkeys, which, after all, can be frozen.
In economist-speak, roses are supply inelastic.
They all have to be harvested within a very short period of time.
They have to be packed and sorted and shipped around the country.
But turkeys can be thrown into a freezer months ahead of time.
So, if you're already thinking about what to get for a special someone next February 14th, here's an idea in economic verse...
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Roses are red, violets are blue, but they're supply inelastic, so instead I got you a frozen turkey.
It doesn't rhyme, but it's a solid investment.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Yee-haw.
You're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
In just a few weeks, the world will descend on London for the Summer Olympic Games.
But then the world goes to London every day.

As Boris Johnson, the former journalist who's just been reelected mayor of London, says in his new book, people from all over the world not only arrive to visit; they have made their lives in London for centuries.
Let Mayor Johnson tell us himself.
Fitzpatrick and others are concerned the reaction to this shooting will to be to blame people who need treatment and further isolate them.
They say people with psychological problems are, in fact, more likely to be the victims of violent crime and need to be encouraged to seek help.
Larry Abramson, NPR News.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
There's an article of faith in politics: always run as an outsider.
And no recent moment better captures that maxim than this one.
It was during a debate between Massachusetts Senate candidates Republican Scott Brown and Democrat Martha Coakley.
Brown was asked a question in which the moderator referred to the so-called Kennedy Senate seat, and Brown replied:
(Soundbite of archival recording)
Well, with all due respect, its not the Kennedy seat, and it's not the Democrats' seat, it's the people's seat.
Many political analysts believe it was that moment when Scott Brown sealed his victory.
But over the past few weeks, a different trend is starting to emerge.
And so we begin the hour with a look at insiders running as insiders.
In at least four states, former governors are going after their old jobs.
There's Iowa Republican Terry Branstad who left the governor's mansion more than a decade ago.
Are you ready for a comeback?
Yeah.
(Soundbite of cheers and applause)
Perhaps even more important question, is Iowa ready for a comeback?
Yeah.
In Oregon, Democrat John Kitzhaber, who retired as governor in 2003, says he's got the resume to do the job again.
I'm running for governor because I believe I have the skills and experience to help.
But this is going to take an effort by all of us.
This can't be just about one person in the governor's office.
Oregon needs you to be there too.
In Georgia, Democratic Governor Roy Barnes was defeated in 2002.
He now says he's learned his lesson and he wants another shot.
Listening is not something I did too much of when I was governor before.
I tried to do too much too fast.
I've learned some lessons.
I learned I should explain myself more.
Unlike Ford or Chrysler, General Motors does not bear the name of a dynamic innovative founder.
But that's not to say that GM's corporate pantheon is lacking an executive star.
The man who made General Motors an industrial giant and epitomized the modern corporate manager was its long time CEO and chairman, Alfred P.
Sloan.
At a news conference today, GM CEO Fritz Henderson spoke of pondering the portrait of Sloan that hangs at GM headquarters.
Unidentified Woman: That's right, Billy Durant.
Exactly.
And what he did is he did his job - he led the company through it.
And I would say that if he were sitting here today, he'd say, do your job.
But how did Alfred P.
Sloan do his job at GM?
We're going to ask William Pelfrey about that.
He's written about Alfred Sloan.
He used to work at General Motors for many years and also is a journalist.
Welcome to the program, Mr. Pelfrey.
Glad to be here.
Alfred P.
Sloan, how would you sum up, in a nutshell, his achievement at General Motors?

Well, he took a loose conglomeration of companies that many people would say made no rhyme or reason the way they were put together, made sense of it and turned it into, indeed, the greatest industrial enterprise the world had ever seen.
Henry Ford famously said you could have a Ford car in any color, so long as it's black.
Alfred P.
Sloan took a very different view of cars and consumers.
Yes.
Sloan took the opposite approach in the early '20s, when he was trying to make sense of the different brands that had been brought into General Motors.
You had Chevrolet, you had Oldsmobile, Buick, Cadillac, Oakland, which - under Sloan - became Pontiac.
Sloan looked at the market and literally created what we call market segmentation.
He divided the vehicle markets into segments by price.
You had Chevrolet at the low end and Cadillac at the high end.
It became known as the price ladder, but Sloan's name for it, as a business model, was a car for every purse and purpose.
A car for every purse and purpose.
Yes.
Considering these two famous leaders of the big automakers: Henry Ford on the one hand and Alfred P.
Sloan on the other, while both are memorialized by foundations and graduate schools and that sort of thing, they were very different characters in real life.
Ford was constantly talking to journalists and writers and being celebrated as a genius.
Sloan, very low-profile character, I gather.
That's right.
Whenever there was a news release, Sloan's name wasn't in it.
It was always General Motors.
And he literally devoted his life to the company.
He lived in a New York City apartment very close to his office, took a sandwich to work every day.
When he was in Detroit on business, he had what he called sleeping rooms put in the 15th floor of the GM building, one floor above the executive suites.
And he would literally sleep above his office in the GM building.
One thing that Alfred P.

Sloan and General Motors are credited with that is not altogether admirable, is almost creating the notion of planned obscelecense, which is: We'll make you a new car, which after you've owned it for 18 months will already feel like an old car, because we phased in new designs and innovations in next year's models.
Fair?
It's kind of a loaded phrase, but he did create the annual model change.
He knew, and his marketing team knew, that people saw their automobile as more than a means of transportation.
They took pride in it.
And so every year, there were planned changes in both the styling and the performance features of the vehicle, so that people would want to buy the new model.
